Currently training Grok 3.5 with heavy focus on reasoning, emphasizing that physics textbooks are valuable for reasoning while social science materials are "totally useless"
Expects there will be several digital superintelligences (maybe 5-10 total, with about 4 in the US) rather than a single runaway AI system
Predicts humanoid robots will outnumber all other robot types combined by approximately 10 to 1, with potentially 5-10 times more humanoid robots than humans
Initially hesitant about AI and robotics due to concerns about creating "Terminator," but realized these developments are inevitable whether he participates or not
Chose to be a participant rather than spectator, now pursuing "pedal to the metal" development of both humanoid robots and digital superintelligence
Believes the combination of deep AI in data centers with robotics will be crucial for future technological progress
Sees Tesla's Optimus robot as part of a broader ecosystem where Tesla works closely with XAI for integrated AI and robotics development
Goals to transfer enough mass to Mars within 30 years to make it self-sustaining, able to continue growing even if Earth supply ships stop coming
Views becoming multi-planetary as essential for increasing the probable lifespan of consciousness and intelligence, both biological and digital
Troubled by the Fermi Paradox and the possibility that intelligence might be incredibly rare, making Earth's consciousness "the tiny candle in a vast darkness"
Sees Mars colonization as the necessary next step before expanding to other star systems, creating a forcing function for space travel improvement
Considers current human civilization at only 1-2% completion of Kardashev Scale 1 (harnessing all planetary energy), with vast room for growth ahead
Considers "rigorous adherence to truth" as the most important factor for AI safety, even when that truth might be politically incorrect
Believes forcing AI to believe untrue things could make it extremely dangerous, emphasizing the need for AI that "loves humanity" and remains helpful
Estimates a 10-20% chance of AI annihilation but emphasizes the 80-90% probability of a great outcome as reason for optimism
Advocates for "maximum truth-seeking AI" and positions XAI's Grok as pursuing this goal to understand fundamental questions about the universe
Hopes AI will help answer existential questions like "where are the aliens," "how did the universe start," and "what level of simulation are we in"
Clarifies that Neuralink is not necessary for digital superintelligence, which will happen before Neuralink reaches scale
Identifies human output bandwidth as extremely limited at less than one bit per second sustained over a full day
Currently has five human patients with read-only implants, allowing tetraplegic patients to control computers and phones with bandwidth similar to fully functioning humans
Plans vision implants within 6-12 months for completely blind patients, writing directly to the visual cortex with eventual multi-spectral capabilities
Envisions long-term augmentation of human intelligence and senses, though this will occur well after digital superintelligence emerges

sec.h: Future of Human Intelligence and Collective Capability
b: Predicts that in the not-distant future, human intelligence will represent a very small percentage of total intelligence
Even with massive intelligence augmentation (everyone having IQ of 1,000), collective human intelligence may be one billionth that of digital intelligence at Kardashev Scale 2
Describes humans as the "biological bootloader for digital superintelligence," questioning whether he was "a good bootloader"
Acknowledges the singularity concept, admitting uncertainty about what will happen when the percentage of human intelligence becomes negligible
Despite these predictions, maintains focus on making humans as useful as possible to fellow human beings during the transition period

summaries.s: IPOs and SPACs are Back, Mag 7 Showdown, Zuck on Tilt, Apple's Fumble, GENIUS Act passes Senate

sec.h: Meta's Aggressive AI Strategy and Talent Acquisition War
b: Zuck's Massive Investment Push: Meta is reportedly offering $100 million signing bonuses and $100+ million annual compensation packages to poach top AI talent from OpenAI, demonstrating Mark Zuckerberg's frustration with falling behind in AI development.

Scale AI Shadow Acquisition: Meta "invested" $14 billion for a 49% stake in Scale AI, which is better described as a shadow acqui-hire to circumvent antitrust scrutiny. Scale CEO Alexander Wang and team will join Meta's new super intelligence division while Scale gets a new CEO.

Strategic Talent Moves: Meta is in talks to hire former GitHub CEO Nat Friedman and Daniel Gross, who have an AI incubator and have invested across the AI ecosystem, bringing both talent and access to portfolio companies' innovations.

Data Labeling Advantage: The Scale acquisition gives Meta access to advanced data labeling techniques crucial for training reasoning models, an area where Meta's Llama models have been underperforming compared to competitors.

Infrastructure Needs: According to Chamath, Meta still lacks the tight hardware-software integration that companies like OpenAI (with Microsoft Azure), Google (with TPUs), and DeepSeek have achieved, which is critical for model performance optimization.

sec.h: Magnificent 7 Performance Divergence and AI Positioning
b: Market Dispersion: For the first time in years, the Mag 7 companies are showing significant performance divergence - Meta up 18%, Google down 8%, NVIDIA up 8%, Tesla down 20%, Apple down 21%, Amazon down 3%, Microsoft up 13%.

Control Your Own Destiny Analysis: Companies are being evaluated on whether they control their AI destiny - Tesla and NVIDIA clearly do, while Amazon lacks its own foundation model and Microsoft has only 49% control through OpenAI.

AI Winners Predictions: The hosts' top picks for achieving super intelligence in 5 years - Chamath: Tesla #1, Google #2; Thomas: NVIDIA #1, Tesla #2; Jason: Elon/Tesla #1, Google #2; Friedberg: Google #1 for portfolio approach, Tesla for humanoid robotics opportunity.

Apple's Innovation Crisis: Apple is criticized for having no clear AI strategy, with Siri remaining dysfunctional after years while competitors deliver functional voice assistants. The company appears to be transitioning from growth to cash cow status.

Google's AI Breadth: Google is praised for its multi-model approach beyond LLMs, including weather forecasting and other specialized applications that demonstrate deep research capabilities across the full stack.

Major IPO Success Stories: Three significant IPOs in recent months - CoreWeave (4x return, $81B market cap), Circle (6x from opening, $48B market cap), and Chime (initially up 40% but then down 20%, $12B market cap).

M&A Activity Surge: Massive acquisition activity including Google/Wiz ($32B), OpenAI acquisitions ($3B and $6.5B), Databricks/Neon ($1B), and Salesforce ($8B), indicating renewed confidence in the market.

Institutional Demand Theory: Friedberg suggests pent-up demand from institutional investors who were overexposed to private equity post-2021 and have been sidelined for three years, creating hunger for new high-growth offerings.

SaaS Market Slowdown: SaaS companies' median growth rate has fallen from 17% in 2021 to 9% today, with only 5% growing above 25% compared to 25% previously, forcing investors to look elsewhere for growth.

AI-Driven Market Opportunity: The combination of declining traditional SaaS growth and massive AI opportunities is creating the potential for the biggest money-making opportunities for investors in decades.

Revenue Per Employee Metrics: AppLovin showcases the future with revenue per employee growing from $3.6M to $7.6M while reducing headcount from 1,000 to 750 employees, demonstrating AI's productivity potential.

Corporate Workforce Reduction: Amazon's Andy Jassy published a manifesto stating they expect to reduce total corporate workforce in coming years while growing 10-20% annually through extensive AI deployment across the company.

Employee Count Predictions: Mixed predictions for Microsoft's future workforce - Chamath and Thomas predict growth due to Azure expansion, while Friedberg predicts decline due to revenue compression from AI disruption.

Custom Software Revolution: Chamath describes how his 30-person team at 8090 can handle hundreds of millions in transactions using AI tools, suggesting entire enterprise software stacks will be rebuilt from scratch.

Demographic Opportunity: Jensen Huang's perspective that aging populations need increased productivity to care for growing elderly populations, making AI-driven efficiency gains socially beneficial rather than just economically disruptive.

GENIUS Act Passage: The stablecoin bill passed the Senate with 68 votes including 18 Democrats, representing a major milestone for crypto regulation after a year of hostility under Gary Gensler's SEC.

Regulatory Framework Requirements: All stablecoin issuers must be audited quarterly by real audits (not attestations), fully reserved 1:1 with dollars in US bank accounts, and offshore issuers like Tether have 3 years to come onshore.

Political Shift Explanation: Sherrod Brown's election loss to crypto-backed Bernie Moreno sent a message to Democrats about the political cost of opposing crypto, with 50 million wallet holders representing significant voter influence.

Banking Industry Compromise: Stablecoin issuers cannot pass interest to token holders due to community bank concerns about competition, though this may be revisited once banks enter the stablecoin market themselves.

Onshoring Benefits: The framework forces offshore competitors like Tether to compete on level ground with compliant US companies like Circle, bringing transparency and consumer protection to the $180+ billion stablecoin market.

sec.h: Software Industry Disruption and Enterprise Transformation
b: Enterprise Software Rebuild: Chamath argues the entire software stack running the world will be rebuilt using AI tools, with his team achieving 50-70% efficiency gains at each step of the development lifecycle.
SaaS Model Breakdown: Consumption-based pricing models are failing (citing Snowflake's struggles) because customers won't accept variable costs for essential data storage and processing needs.

Corporate IT Transformation: Companies with $18 billion annual IT budgets represent massive disruption opportunities, as AI enables custom solutions that cost tens of millions versus hundreds of millions in software licenses.

S&P 493 Disruption Potential: Beyond the Mag 7, there's potential for unprecedented dispersion between companies that adopt AI rebuilding versus those that don't, creating major investment opportunities.

Communication Gap Problem: The disconnect between technical IT organizations and business leadership (CEO/CFO/Board) enables continued overspending on legacy software that AI could replace more efficiently.

summaries.s: The US Bombed Iran. Now What? | TED Explains the World with Ian Bremmer

sec.h: Background and Context of the US Attack on Iran
b: On June 21, 2025, the US bombed three nuclear sites in Iran, marking a significant escalation that plunged the world into uncertainty and joined the ongoing Israel-Iran conflict
The attack specifically targeted Iran's nuclear capabilities, including the critical underground facility at Fordow, which is located 100 meters under rock and concrete beneath a mountain
Iran had been ramping up uranium enrichment and stockpiling highly enriched uranium after Trump withdrew from the JCPOA nuclear deal, bringing them closer to potential nuclear weapons capability
US and Israeli intelligence communities disagreed on how close Iran was to developing nuclear weapons, with Americans not convinced Iran was covertly working toward breakout capability
Iran was not in compliance with international inspectors and was secreting parts of their nuclear program, creating the justification for military action

sec.h: Israel's Role in Escalating the Conflict
b: Israel initiated the war by attacking multiple Iranian military sites and assassinating key military leaders, including officials involved in US-Iran nuclear negotiations
The Israelis lacked the capability to destroy the critical Fordow facility, as they didn't have B-2 bombers, trained pilots, or bunker-buster bombs necessary for the mission
Israel specifically pushed the US to take military action against the underground nuclear facility that was beyond their own military capabilities
Over 30 Iranian military leaders have been assassinated by Israel, leaving Iran with less experienced, more junior leadership in critical positions
Israel continues to be in a state of war with Iran and wants the United States to maintain an ongoing state of war, not just one-time strikes

sec.h: Trump's Decision-Making Process and Diplomatic Efforts
b: Trump spent a week attempting final negotiations with Iran before ordering the attack, using special envoy Steve Witkoff for direct communications
The Iranian government refused to accept voluntary dismantlement of their entire nuclear program with inspections, viewing this as too critical for regime legitimacy
Trump publicly demanded Iranian surrender of their nuclear program, which Iran found unacceptable, leaving military action as the only alternative
The Trump administration maintains this is not a regime change effort and hopes to compel Iran back to negotiations despite conducting acts of war
Trump has experience with Iranian military actions from his first term, having ordered the assassination of Qasem Soleimani with limited Iranian retaliation
Trump's support for Israel has remained consistently strong, contrary to media speculation about growing distance between the two leaders
During Trump's first presidency, he implemented the Abraham Accords, recognized Israeli sovereignty over Golan Heights, and moved the US Embassy to Jerusalem
Netanyahu was the first foreign leader invited to meet Trump in the Oval Office after Liberation Day, demonstrating continued prioritization of the relationship
While Trump and Netanyahu had contentious phone calls during the crisis, Trump never threatened to cut military aid or intelligence support to Israel
The US provides Israel with billions in military support and critical intelligence processing capabilities that are essential for Israeli operations

sec.h: Potential Iranian Response and Military Capabilities
b: Iran's parliament approved measures to potentially close the Strait of Hormuz, though this is largely seen as rhetorical flourish rather than serious policy
Closing the Strait of Hormuz would be essentially suicidal for Iran, as the US has more naval and air power in the Persian Gulf than at any time since the Iraq War
More likely Iranian responses include attacks on US military assets through Shia militias in Iraq or Houthis in Yemen, rather than direct Iranian action
Approximately 40,000 US service members in the region are within reach of Iranian ballistic missiles and proxy threats, making them vulnerable targets
Iranian state media is portraying the US attacks as weak and causing only peripheral damage to maintain regime stability and popular support

sec.h: Command Structure Concerns and Risk of Escalation
b: Iran's 85-year-old Supreme Leader is hiding in a bunker without internet access, making military communication more challenging than usual
The assassination of numerous experienced Iranian military leaders raises concerns about less experienced commanders potentially acting without central authorization
There are significant risks of rogue Iranian military leaders ordering attacks that could dramatically escalate the conflict beyond central government control
Trump has publicly stated that the US knows the Supreme Leader's location and could kill him if necessary, serving as a deterrent against major escalation
The fog of war and deteriorating Iranian command structure increases the possibility of irrational or uncoordinated Iranian responses
Unlike the Gaza conflict where Israel was globally isolated, European allies, Britain, Canada, and others support Israeli actions against Iran's nuclear program
Only Finland among EU members condemned the Israeli attacks on Iran, with most other allies providing at least tacit support
Gulf states privately welcome actions against Iranian military capabilities despite public opposition, as they don't want Iran to have nuclear weapons
China, despite getting significant oil from Iran, is playing a minimal diplomatic role and offering little meaningful support to Iran
Gulf states are concerned about potential threats to energy exports but are not committed friends of Iran and benefit from reduced Iranian capabilities

sec.h: Russia's Limited Response and Strategic Calculations
b: Russian attacks on Ukraine have intensified during the Iran crisis, taking advantage of diverted international attention from the Ukraine conflict
Despite Iran being a key military supplier to Russia with drone factories and ammunition, Russia is providing minimal support to Iran during this crisis
Putin maintains reasonable relationships with both Iran and Israel, including guarantees for Russian scientists working at Iranian nuclear sites
Russia's failure to significantly support Iran demonstrates Tehran's isolation and lack of reliable international allies
The Iranian leadership recognizes their global isolation, which serves as a restraining factor against major escalatory responses

sec.h: Domestic US Political Dynamics and MAGA Base
b: Core MAGA ideology emphasizes anti-war sentiment rooted in isolationist, "America First" thinking, creating potential tension with military action
Trump's messaging to his base emphasizes that destroying Iran's nuclear capabilities aligns with MAGA principles and doesn't constitute betrayal
MAGA supporters generally oppose prolonged ground wars but are more accepting of quick, decisive military strikes like the TikTok war model
Trump risks losing base support if the conflict evolves into an extended "Israel First" rather than "America First" commitment
Trump is currently 0 for 3 on his promise to end ongoing wars (Russia-Ukraine, Israel-Gaza, Israel-Iran), creating political pressure for quick resolution
The NATO summit in The Hague is expected to be more successful than recent G7 meetings, with major announcements about increased defense spending
NATO allies will announce a 5% defense spending target (3.5% hard defense, 1.5% defense-related infrastructure), significantly higher than previous commitments
Trump's approach to Ukraine has shifted from aid-based support to critical minerals deals, framing assistance as protecting US economic interests
NATO members are generally more supportive of US-Israeli actions against Iran compared to their positions on Gaza operations
The NATO relationship has significantly improved from its low point following earlier tensions over European relations and Ukraine policy
Successful containment of the conflict depends on Iran not responding with major escalation and Israel not successfully dragging the US deeper into war
Failed containment could lead to regional conflagration, oil prices over $120, and global recession
Iran's energy export capabilities remain undamaged, giving them incentive to avoid actions that would invite destruction of these assets
The conflict's trajectory will significantly impact global energy markets and economic stability, particularly if shipping through the Strait of Hormuz is disrupted
Gulf states' economies could be deeply undermined if the war escalates beyond current containment levels, affecting global energy supplies

summaries.s: Iran War Debate: Nuclear Weapons, Trump, Peace, Power & the Middle East

sec.h: Recent Iran-Israel War and Trump's Military Action
b: Operation Midnight Hammer: Trump authorized B-II bombers to drop 12 massive ordnance penetrators (30,000-pound bombs) on Iran's Fordow nuclear facility, following Israeli strikes on other Iranian nuclear sites over 12 days

Diplomatic Context: The strikes occurred after Iran rejected Trump's offer during five rounds of negotiations in Oman, where the US proposed allowing temporary above-ground enrichment in exchange for rendering below-ground facilities non-operational
Ceasefire Achievement: Trump forced both Iran and Israel into a tentative ceasefire, offering Iran another chance to return to negotiations in Oman while demonstrating American military capability

Strategic Messaging: Trump's approach combined military pressure with diplomatic outreach, telling Iran they could either negotiate or face continued strikes, while maintaining that regime change was not the goal
Immediate Aftermath: Iran responded with symbolic missile strikes on US bases in Qatar and Iraq with zero casualties, suggesting restraint rather than escalation

sec.h: Iran's Nuclear Program: Technical Capabilities and Intentions
b: Enrichment Levels Explained: Iran has accumulated 15-17 bombs worth of 60% enriched uranium, which represents 99% of the technical steps needed to reach 90% weapons-grade uranium, with only 1% more enrichment required

Three Components of Nuclear Weapons: A deliverable nuclear weapon requires weapons-grade uranium, delivery vehicles (missiles), and a warhead - Iran has extensive missile capabilities (3,000 missiles, 2,000 capable of reaching Israel) and ICBM development

Uranium vs Plutonium Routes: Iran lacks reprocessing facilities for plutonium weapons and their heavy water reactor at Arak was disabled under the JCPOA, leaving uranium enrichment as their primary path to nuclear weapons

Breakout Timeline Estimates: US intelligence suggests Iran could develop a crude nuclear device in 4-6 months or a deliverable warhead in 18 months, though a gun-type uranium bomb would be easier but less militarily useful

Latent Deterrent Strategy: Scott Horton argues Iran's position has been to maintain a "threshold" nuclear capability as deterrence, similar to Japan, Germany, and Brazil, rather than actively pursuing weapons

AMAD Program Controversy: Mark Dubowitz cites the alleged pre-2003 Iranian nuclear weapons program called AMAD, supposedly designed to build five atomic warheads, based on documents from the Mossad-obtained archive

Scott Horton's Counterargument: Claims the archive documents are recycled forgeries from the discredited "smoking laptop" of 2005, originally funneled through the MEK (Iranian opposition group) and Israeli intelligence
2007 National Intelligence Estimate: US intelligence concluded Iran halted nuclear weapons research in 2003 after the US invasion of Iraq, with no evidence of weapons development since then

David Albright's Analysis: Nuclear expert David Albright wrote extensively about the Iranian archive, but Horton argues Albright previously debunked key claims about warhead designs being incompatible with Iran's missile nose cones
Current Intelligence Assessment: Recent US intelligence under Trump's administration maintains Iran has not made the political decision to pursue nuclear weapons, despite building capabilities

sec.h: The JCPOA Nuclear Deal: Successes and Failures
b: Deal Structure: The 2015 JCPOA allowed Iran limited enrichment capabilities but required shipping enriched uranium to Russia, imposed restrictions on advanced centrifuges, and provided sanctions relief
Sunset Provisions Problem: Mark Dubowitz opposed the deal because restrictions would expire by 2031, potentially allowing Iran to emerge with industrial-scale enrichment capabilities
Trump's Withdrawal: Both debaters agree Trump should have tried to renegotiate the deal with European allies to extend sunset clauses rather than withdrawing unilaterally in 2018
European Resistance: Trump administration efforts to modify the deal failed because European partners (UK, France, Germany) refused to renegotiate terms with Iran

Russiagate Impact: Scott Horton argues the false accusations against Trump regarding Russia paralyzed his ability to engage in effective diplomacy, including potentially using Russian influence with Iran

sec.h: Core Disagreement on Iran's Nuclear Intentions
b: Horton's Position: Iran seeks a "latent nuclear deterrent" - demonstrating capability without building weapons, using nuclear knowledge as leverage to prevent attacks while remaining within negotiable bounds
Dubowitz's Position: Iran has consistently worked toward nuclear weapons capability, spending half a trillion dollars on a program that makes no commercial sense for civilian energy production

Evidence Interpretation: Fundamental disagreement over whether Iran's underground facilities, weapons scientist network, and 60% enrichment represent defensive preparation or offensive weapons development
Recent Escalation: Horton argues the recent attacks make Iran more likely to pursue actual weapons, while Dubowitz believes military pressure will force diplomatic resolution
Intelligence Community Views: Both cite US intelligence assessments but interpret them differently regarding Iran's ultimate nuclear intentions
Scott Horton's Libertarian Approach: Based on the non-aggression principle, advocates for minimal government, non-interventionism, and opposes maintaining global military empire
Thomas Jefferson's Legacy: Cites Jefferson's call for "peace, commerce, and honest friendship with all nations and entangling alliances with none" as the proper American foreign policy framework

Nuclear Deterrence Philosophy: Argues America could defend itself with minimal nuclear deterrent (citing Ron Paul's "couple of good submarines" comment) rather than massive military industrial complex
Historical Precedent: Points to Reagan-Gorbachev near-agreement on total nuclear disarmament at Reykjavik in 1986 as proof that ambitious disarmament is possible
Peace Through Strength Alternative: Mark Dubowitz argues American military deterrence prevents wars by making enemies believe the US will credibly use force when necessary

sec.h: Foundation for Defense of Democracies Philosophy
b: American Indispensable Power: Mark Dubowitz argues America has maintained the rules-based international order since WWII, enabling European and Asian recovery and global prosperity
Deterrence Strategy: Believes showing enemies that America will use "selective, narrow, overwhelming, and deadly" force prevents larger conflicts from developing
Democracy Promotion Limits: FDD does not believe in forcing democracy worldwide, particularly in the Middle East, preferring stability and counter-terrorism cooperation
Iran as Special Case: Views Iran differently from other threshold nuclear states due to its history of terrorism, killing Americans, and revolutionary ideology since 1979
Axis of Resistance: Sees Iran's network of proxy forces (Hezbollah, Hamas, Houthis, Iraqi militias) as evidence of aggressive regional expansion requiring containment

sec.h: Historical Context: World War II and Interventionism
b: Isolationism Debate: Discussion of 1930s American isolationist movement and how Hitler miscalculated US resolve, drawing parallels to how adversaries might misread American intentions today
Overlearning History: Both agree on dangers of applying WWII lessons inappropriately to every modern conflict, but disagree on current threat assessment
Pearl Harbor Precedent: Scott Horton notes America only entered WWII after being attacked, suggesting this as the proper threshold for military intervention
Gathering Storm Theory: Mark Dubowitz argues early action against emerging threats prevents larger wars, citing the failure to stop Hitler earlier in the 1930s
Unique Evil Principle: Both acknowledge Hitler represented unique evil that doesn't apply to current adversaries, despite frequent historical comparisons in political rhetoric

sec.h: Nuclear Proliferation Concerns and Future Scenarios
b: Middle East Cascade: Mark Dubowitz warns that Iranian nuclear weapons would trigger proliferation among Saudi Arabia, Turkey, and other regional powers who have stated intentions to match Iranian capabilities
Indo-Pacific Impact: Concerns that US failure to stop Iran could undermine nuclear security guarantees to Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan, potentially driving them toward their own weapons programs
Non-Proliferation Treaty Erosion: Scott Horton argues US attacks on Iran (an NPT signatory) by Israel (non-NPT nuclear state) undermines the entire non-proliferation framework
Gold Standard Alternative: Mark Dubowitz advocates for the "gold standard" model (no enrichment/reprocessing) used successfully with 23 countries for civilian nuclear energy
Russian/Chinese Response: Discussion of potential retaliation through nuclear technology sharing with Iran or other US adversaries if military pressure continues
Abraham Accords Success: Mark Dubowitz points to UAE, Bahrain, and Morocco peace agreements with Israel as evidence that Arab states see Iran, not Israel, as primary threat
Syrian Complexity: Both express concern about new Syrian leadership under former Al-Qaeda affiliate, though Mark sees potential if properly managed
Saudi-Israel Normalization: Potential for broader regional agreement contingent on resolving Iranian nuclear issue and Israeli-Palestinian conflict
Cyrus Accords Vision: Mark's proposal for eventual US-Israel-Iran agreement, named after Persian king who returned Jews from exile
Sectarian Considerations: Discussion of Sunni-Shia dynamics, with Mark arguing Iran exploits these divisions while building cross-sectarian anti-American alliances

sec.h: Iran's Terrorist Network and American Casualties
b: Historical Attacks: Mark Dubowitz cites decades of Iranian-backed terrorism including 1983 Beirut barracks bombing, Khobar Towers, and Iraq War casualties

Scott Horton's Rebuttals: Disputes Iranian responsibility for many attacks, citing Michael Scheuer (former CIA bin Laden unit chief) and other sources suggesting Al-Qaeda responsibility for Khobar Towers
EFP Controversy: Extensive debate over "explosively formed penetrators" used against US forces in Iraq, with Horton citing multiple sources showing Iraqi Shia Arabs manufactured them locally
Israeli Intelligence Role: Horton cites Victor Ostrovsky (former Mossad officer) claiming Israel knew about 1983 Beirut attack but didn't warn Americans
Hezbollah Origins: Disagreement over whether Hezbollah formed before or in response to Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982

sec.h: Current Policy Recommendations and Future Scenarios
b: Best Case Scenario: Both agree on need for negotiated settlement - Mark wants zero enrichment/full dismantlement, Scott accepts enrichment with strong safeguards similar to JCPOA
Worst Case Outcomes: Range from continued Iranian nuclear development to full US military invasion, with both agreeing that regime change/invasion would be catastrophic
Trump's Approach: Mark praises Trump's selective use of force combined with diplomatic outreach, avoiding both passivity and overcommitment
Sanctions and Incentives: Discussion of balancing sanctions pressure with positive incentives for Iranian compliance, including civilian nuclear cooperation
Regional Security Architecture: Both see potential for broader Middle East peace if Iranian nuclear issue resolved, though through different approaches

summaries.s: The Founder of Jimmy Choo: Tamara Mellon

b: Tamara Mellon's life story mirrors a "Danielle Steel novel" with a plucky heroine facing numerous obstacles and villains throughout her entrepreneurial journey

Her father provided seed money for Jimmy Choo but warned her "Don't let the accountants run your business," which became prophetic as the struggle between financial and creative forces dominated her 15-year tenure

Despite building Jimmy Choo into a billion-dollar brand, Mellon's personal glamour kept her in global media spotlight, with Vogue photographing her wedding and Vanity Fair covering her divorce and criminal trial
Her seemingly glamorous beginnings in London and Beverly Hills mansions were marked by tumultuous family life, battles with anxiety and depression, and a stint in rehab
She was determined not to end up unemployed, penniless, and living under her alcoholic mother's control, which drove her to hone her business instincts and invest in fashion
Mellon's story begins with her getting fired from Vogue after arriving two hours late, having consumed "prodigious quantities of cocaine and vodka" the night before
Despite working hard for five years at Vogue, her after-hours indiscretions led to her termination, which she later recognized as "a huge favor" that set forces in motion for her future success
Getting fired forced her to confront her personal crisis and develop a plan, following self-help advice to identify what she loved and was good at: fashion, particularly shoes
She had been developing an entrepreneurial idea about a London cobbler named Jimmy Choo who made bespoke shoes and worked with Vogue on fashion shoots
Her experience at Vogue taught her the power of media to drive sales, as fashion credits would lead wealthy customers to Jimmy's shop
Before Jimmy Choo, Mellon worked in prestigious retail, public relations, and fashion media, experiences that contributed significantly to her later success
Her understanding of her target customer was fundamental: "I was the customer that I wanted to reach," giving her insight into where they shopped, what they read, and what TV shows they watched
She positioned herself as the first customer, understanding that people like her would appreciate the shoes she liked
This customer insight became crucial for product development, store placement, marketing strategies, and understanding the luxury consumer mindset
Her previous work gave her insider knowledge of the fashion industry that proved invaluable when creating her own brand
Mellon's first memory is of her mother throwing her across a bed, with her head hitting a radiator, establishing a pattern of psychological abuse
Her mother was an alcoholic with severe emotional problems who engaged in "steady drip, drip, drip of psychological assaults," calling Tamara stupid, lazy, and ugly
The abuse created one of Mellon's primary driving forces: "a demonic drive for the financial security I hope would keep me out of her clutches"
Her worst fear was remaining under her mother's control, which motivated her relentless pursuit of success and independence
At an early age, she learned to "shut down and never show any emotion, either happy or sad" as a survival mechanism against the psychological torture
Despite not protecting her from her mother's abuse during childhood, Mellon's father became her co-founder, advisor, and main supporter as adults
He was a successful entrepreneur who had helped scale Vidal Sassoon, selling the business for $72 million just before they founded Jimmy Choo
Their relationship strengthened as they worked together, with her father providing a "kitchen MBA" through dinner table business discussions
She describes feeling "a bond growing between my father and me that had never been allowed to flourish during my childhood"
He was charismatic, refined, and maintained "understated elegance," always flying first class and wearing bespoke suits, commanding presence in any room
After getting out of rehab, Mellon spent three months daily at Jimmy Choo's shop, demonstrating commitment and learning the business to convince him to partner
The basic partnership was 50-50, with Jimmy designing shoes while Mellon managed manufacturing, sales, and marketing
They started with only $150,000 from her father, making the company profitable from day one with remarkable efficiency
Her pitch to Jimmy: open stores, create wholesale lines for high-end stores worldwide, and "both become incredibly rich"
The key insight was transforming Jimmy from a bespoke cobbler into a manufacturer of luxury shoes for the mass affluent market
Mellon chose their first store location on Motcomb Street based on deep understanding of her target customers' shopping patterns
She criticized competitor Manolo Blahnik for being "20 minutes from the nearest tube station," making it inconvenient for working women to visit during lunch
Her strategy mirrored Steve Jobs' Apple Store concept of "ambushing customers" by placing stores in high-traffic areas despite higher rent costs
The location decision proved crucial when the creator of Sex and the City stumbled upon the store and fell in love with the shoes
This strategic thinking demonstrated understanding that customers would walk "20 footsteps" but not drive "20 minutes" for shopping convenience
Initial manufacturing attempts were disasters, with samples covered in black scuff marks and awful stitching, forcing them to sell from sketches
Mellon discovered Jimmy had no interest in design, forcing her to become the creative force behind the brand
She found inspiration at flea markets, combining different elements to create new designs, and discovered new materials at Italian trade shows
Her approach was emotional and intuitive: "the things that struck me and that I related to emotionally, other women related to as well"
This paralleled Quentin Tarantino's filmmaking philosophy of creating for himself as the audience, having been obsessed with the medium before creating
Mellon understood from her Vogue experience that magazine features could reach hundreds of thousands of potential customers
She recognized that celebrities were becoming more important than models for driving sales and media attention
Their strategy involved gifting shoes to celebrities, their stylists, agents, and lawyers to maximize exposure through multiple client relationships
A single stylist could provide access to five or ten celebrities, making relationship-building with stylists particularly valuable
Oscar night became a major annual focus, with Mellon staying up all night orchestrating shoe gifting to nominees and attendees
Kate Winslet's mention of wearing Jimmy Choo shoes at the 1998 Oscars (when nominated for Titanic) had such positive sales impact that Oscar night became an annual priority
Sex and the City's first mention on July 5, 1998, with Carrie Bradshaw screaming "I lost my Choo" catapulted them to household name status
The show ultimately mentioned Jimmy Choo 34 times, providing millions of dollars in free product placement
A buyer from Saks Fifth Avenue discovered them at a trade show and immediately ordered 3,000 pairs, cracking the wholesale market
First-year sales reached $250,000 with only $15,000 in shop costs and minimal staff, demonstrating remarkable efficiency
Matthew Mellon was the great-great-great grandson of Judge Thomas Mellon, representing the decline of a once-powerful dynasty
He became addicted to cocaine and crack, hiring limos with rotating drivers to party around the clock while coked out of his mind
On their wedding night, Mellon went to her room alone while Matthew "partied until dawn," establishing the pattern of their marriage
She often had to track him down through his limo company and once found him in a crack house while she worked daily building the business
His drug addiction and alcoholism reached the point of psychosis, creating additional stress while she managed a growing company and new motherhood

sec.h: Loss of Control and Private Equity Problems
b: Jimmy Choo's decision to sell his 50% stake to Phoenix Equity Partners for $8-10 million marked the beginning of Mellon's loss of control
Against her father's advice, she agreed to give Phoenix 51% control because she was "desperate to get rid of Jimmy" due to their bad relationship
This 1% difference meant "someone else would now have the final say in how we ran the company," fundamentally changing the business dynamics
The private equity partners were "all about the exit," focused on maximizing short-term EBITDA rather than long-term brand building
She learned that "the founder is no longer in control," leading to decisions that conflicted with her vision for the brand
Private equity partners canceled a £200,000 sponsorship of the British Academy of Film and Television Awards dinner to preserve EBITDA
This decision wasted an opportunity comparable to their successful Oscar night strategy, showing the disconnect between founder and financial partners
Partners pushed for cheaper materials, limiting leather costs to €30 per square meter and forcing factories to cut corners in manufacturing
They refused to refurbish decade-old stores, prioritizing immediate financial returns over brand maintenance and customer experience
Mellon felt "treated like an employee at the company I had founded," losing influence over creative and strategic decisions
Between 2001 and 2017, Jimmy Choo changed hands six times: Phoenix Equity Partners, Lion Capital, Tower Brook Capital Partners, Labelux, IPO, and finally Michael Kors Holdings
Each transition required costly due diligence processes that became "a tiresome second job," distracting from actual business operations
Sale prices increased from $101 million (2004) to $1.2 billion (2017), showing the brand's continued growth despite management conflicts
Competitors weren't facing the same distractions and could focus on "the real work of creating and maintaining quality and innovation"
The constant ownership changes created instability and prevented long-term strategic planning and brand development
Mellon's father died unexpectedly from an aneurysm on April 19, 2004, taking 18 hours to die while she held him and tried to say goodbye
His death removed her "one solid rock" and left her without her mentor, business partner, and emotional support system
Her mother sued her for more money despite having no role in building Jimmy Choo, representing the ultimate betrayal from family
The lawsuit cost Mellon $4 million, with half going to legal fees before her mother finally withdrew the case
This marked the final severing of their relationship after 40 years, leaving Mellon feeling "empty and alone" despite winning

sec.h: Breaking the Cycle and Final Departure
b: The accumulated stress from business conflicts, personal tragedies, and family lawsuits led to "massive anxiety attacks and night sweats"
Mellon couldn't sleep, took hours to dress, couldn't make decisions, and couldn't stand being with other people
On August 1, 2011, exactly 15 years after her first trade show, she gave notice and left the company she founded
Her departure combined "anger, relief, mourning, and a profound sense of loss" after dedicating her life energy to building the brand
She emphasizes the personal nature of entrepreneurship, calling it "bullshit when people say it's not personal, it's business—for founders, it's always personal"
Her most fundamental advice is "always retain majority ownership and control" and "follow your instincts" rather than being "blown back and forth by conflicting opinions"
She warns against letting wrong partners with short-term thinking compromise product quality and brand integrity
The importance of understanding your customer deeply, being that customer yourself, and maintaining "soul in the game" like Steve Jobs
Entrepreneurs should focus on building the best product possible rather than settling for mediocrity, as "mediocrity is invisible until passion shows up and exposes it"
The value of persistence, strategic thinking, and understanding the power of media and celebrity influence in building luxury brands
Despite missing the close mother-daughter relationship she craved, Mellon found redemption in her relationship with her own daughter
She treasures morning moments when her daughter climbs under the covers for hugs and chats before school, calling it "the greatest gift"
Breaking the cycle of abuse and creating the loving relationship she never had represents a profound personal victory
Her mother denied herself "the pleasure of this kind of relationship," but Mellon chose differently as a parent
The book's final message encapsulates her journey: "It may have seemed that now and then I needed a rescuer, but over time I learned to rescue myself"

summaries.s: IEA Oil 2025 Report Summary

sec.h: Global Oil Demand Forecast to Peak This Decade
b: Global oil demand is projected to increase by 2.5 mb/d from 2024 to 2030, reaching a plateau around 105.5 mb/d by the end of the decade, with annual growth slowing from roughly 700 kb/d in 2025-26 to just a trickle over the next several years.

A small decline is expected in 2030 based on current policy settings and market trends, driven by below-trend economic growth, weighed down by global trade tensions and fiscal imbalances, and accelerating substitution away from oil in transport and power generation sectors.

Electric vehicles are set to displace 5.4 mb/d of global oil demand by 2030, with global electric car sales exceeding 17 million in 2024 and expected to surpass 20 million in 2025, representing around one-quarter of all cars sold.

Substitution away from oil will also feature prominently in power generation, particularly in Saudi Arabia, where displacement of oil burning by natural gas and renewables drives the single largest decline in oil demand for any country through 2030.
Demand for oil from combustible fossil fuels (excluding petrochemical feedstocks and biofuels) may peak as early as 2027, with CO2 emissions from oil use forecast to hit an apex by 2027.

sec.h: Petrochemicals Become Dominant Driver of Oil Demand Growth
b: The petrochemical industry is set to become the dominant source of global oil demand growth from 2026 onwards, closely linked to the burgeoning supply of natural gas liquids (NGLs).

By 2030, the production of polymers and synthetic fibres will require 18.4 mb/d of oil, or more than one in every six barrels, with petrochemical feedstocks' share of total oil consumption rising from 15.8% in 2024 to 17.4% by 2030.

China and the United States lead the build-out of petrochemical capacity, at the expense of Europe and other economies in Asia, with feedstocks accounting for 24% of total oil demand in 2030 compared to 22% in 2024.

The shift toward petrochemicals reflects steady growth in underlying plastics use rather than acceleration, as this sector is not subject to factors comparable to vehicle efficiency gains or widespread substitution effects on the scale of transport electrification.

Rising use of oil products as raw materials for plastics and synthetic fibres cemented petrochemicals' dominance of overall oil demand growth in 2024, accounting for about three-quarters of net growth.

sec.h: Regional Demand Patterns Show Stark Divergence
b: Robust oil demand growth of 4.2 mb/d in emerging and developing economies over 2024-30 contrasts sharply with a continued contraction in advanced economies, with OECD oil consumption forecast to decline by 1.7 mb/d through 2030.

India leads global demand growth with an expected 1 mb/d increase, the largest of any single country by far, driven by stellar GDP expansion at an average annual rate of 2.8% and rising middle-class consumption.

China's total oil consumption in 2030 is now set to be only marginally higher than in 2024 (30 kb/d increase), compared with growth of around 1 mb/d forecast previously, due to rapid EV penetration and economic structural shifts.

The United States sees an increase in forecast oil demand of 1.1 mb/d by 2030 compared to last year's report, due to lower gasoline prices and a loss of momentum in EV adoption, with EVs expected to account for 20% of US car sales in 2030, down from 55% assumed last year.
Asian markets dominate growth overall, with rising oil use in Southeast Asian economies (Tiger Cubs) also significant, while consumption among OECD countries declines across all major regions.

sec.h: Oil Supply Capacity Growth Outpaces Demand
b: World oil production capacity is forecast to rise by 5.1 mb/d to 114.7 mb/d by 2030, led by Saudi Arabia and the United States, significantly outpacing the projected 2.5 mb/d increase in global oil demand.

Global NGL production is expected to increase by 2.3 mb/d to 20.1 mb/d by 2030, accounting for nearly half the total increase in world oil production capacity, driven by strategic focus on natural gas developments by Middle East producers and associated gas from US shale operations.
Net capacity growth through 2030 is roughly twice the projected increase in oil demand, with OPEC+ spare crude capacity (excluding Iran, Venezuela, and Russia) estimated to reach 6.5 mb/d in 2030.
Supply capacity growth is heavily frontloaded, slipping from 1.8 mb/d in 2025 to contraction after 2029 as the pipeline of non-OPEC+ projects wanes, while mirroring demand trends.
Based on current OPEC+ supply trajectory, implied stock builds of nearly 2 mb/d are projected at the end of the forecast period, suggesting downward pressure on prices.

sec.h: US Shale Growth Slows While Other Regions Rise
b: US liquids output growth is expected to slow markedly as crude plateaus, with light tight oil (LTO) production increasing by only 360 kb/d from 2024 to 2030, reaching 9.8 mb/d, while NGL growth remains more robust at 860 kb/d.

The United States remains the second-largest contributor to medium-term supply capacity growth behind Saudi Arabia, adding 880 kb/d over 2024-30 to reach 21.1 mb/d, but crude oil production is expected to decline by 60 kb/d to 13.1 mb/d.
Non-OPEC+ Americas quintet (United States, Canada, Brazil, Guyana, and Argentina) will boost production by 2.8 mb/d by 2030, with their combined output approaching one-third of global oil supply.
Argentina's Vaca Muerta LTO production is projected to more than double from 400 kb/d in 2024 to 890 kb/d by 2030, supported by new takeaway capacity and economic reforms under President Milei.

Production growth in Guyana and Brazil will lose momentum from 2028 onwards as the number of sanctioned projects tails off, while Canadian output benefits from improved pipeline egress and continued shale drilling.

sec.h: OPEC+ Strategy Shifts Amid Market Pressures
b: The OPEC+ alliance has begun unwinding voluntary supply cuts of more than 2 mb/d that have been in place since 2023, with a decision to start unwinding oil production curbs in May 2025 resetting oil supply trajectories.

The group of eight OPEC+ countries that agreed to cut production by 2.2 mb/d announced 1.4 mb/d of target increases for May-July 2025, though only Saudi Arabia has room to substantially raise production.

Saudi Arabia leads OPEC+ capacity growth through the decade, gaining almost 1.2 mb/d, primarily through massive Jafurah unconventional resource development and focus on natural gas to reduce crude oil use in power generation.

The UAE is set to lead global crude oil capacity additions with over 720 kb/d by 2030, while Iraq increases capacity by 560 kb/d to 5.4 mb/d, though short of its 6 mb/d target due to infrastructure constraints.
Combined with forecast slowdown in oil demand, the call on OPEC+ crude in 2030 is 1.2 mb/d below the average 2025 call, suggesting potential oversupply if current production levels are maintained.

sec.h: Global Trade Patterns Undergo Major Shifts
b: The Atlantic Basin crude surplus is expected to widen by approximately 870 kb/d to 7.1 mb/d by 2030, as European and US refining activity slows while oil supply in the Americas continues to expand.
Middle East crude exports are projected to increase from 16.1 mb/d in 2024 to 17.9 mb/d by 2030, equivalent to the combined exports from the Americas, Africa, and Eurasia.

Brazilian and Guyanese crude exports will increasingly head east as 800 kb/d of additional supplies boost Central and South America's crude exports to 4 mb/d by 2030, following the pattern of increased North American exports to Asia.

The Middle East is set to lead regional product export gains over the decade, driven by higher LPG, naphtha, and fuel oil volumes, while several countries that drove recent expansion in product exports will see limited progress.
Atlantic Basin product exports rise by 320 kb/d to 3.5 mb/d as regional demand for refined products contracts more rapidly than local production adjustments.

Global refined products demand is projected to peak in 2027 at 86.3 mb/d, only 710 kb/d above 2024 levels, before accelerating declines in gasoline and diesel use outweigh growth in naphtha and jet fuel.

Despite tepid demand growth projections, 4.2 mb/d of new refining capacity is expected globally by 2030, partly offset by 1.6 mb/d of closures, with net capacity growth far exceeding refined product demand.

The refining industry faces mounting challenges from oil demand growth underpinned almost exclusively by petrochemical feedstocks produced from non-refined products such as NGLs, marginalizing refineries' role in meeting petrochemical demand.

High-cost regions like Europe and the US West Coast are most likely to see further capacity cuts, with announced shutdowns totaling 1.6 mb/d for 2025-30, equivalent to an annual decline of around 250 kb/d.
Refineries must adapt to shifting demand dynamics with tougher challenges ahead, as the long-term trend of rising transport fuel demand that underpinned investment strategy for 50 years reverses.

Europe faces the steepest regional decline in product demand at just over 900 kb/d to 12.8 mb/d by 2030, with refinery runs projected to drop nearly 900 kb/d and capacity at risk rising by 650 kb/d to 1.6 mb/d.

European refiners face structurally challenging future with rising carbon compliance costs, as EU Emissions Trading System allowances increase from approximately EUR 30/t in 2021 to around EUR 70/t currently.

No expansions or greenfield projects are expected in OECD Europe over the forecast period, with announced closures totaling 370 kb/d by 2030 and potential for substantially more in the latter part of the decade.

Major 2025 closures include Shell's 150 kb/d Wesseling facility in Germany, BP's 80 kb/d Gelsenkirchen unit, and the 140 kb/d Petroineos Grangemouth facility in the UK, marking the region's largest annual capacity reduction since 2012.
Free carbon allowance allocations for refineries are being progressively phased out, with allocations down 20% by 2025 relative to 2020 levels and expected to decline by over 40% by 2030.

sec.h: US West Coast Refining Undergoes Major Contraction
b: US West Coast (PADD 5) refining capacity faces sustained contraction with over 700 kb/d of crude distillation capacity closed or scheduled for closure between 2018 and 2026, representing nearly one-quarter of operational baseline.

Recent and planned closures include Phillips 66's 120 kb/d Rodeo facility (2024), 140 kb/d Wilmington refinery (Q4 2025), and Valero's 145 kb/d Benicia refinery (H1 2026), leaving only 12 crude oil refineries in California.

Closures are driven not by poor margins but by financial and policy challenges including stringent environmental compliance costs, extensive permitting hurdles, and unique fuel specifications like CARBOB gasoline.

The pace of refinery closures outpaces the transition to EVs and more efficient vehicles, keeping the region net short on products and requiring continued imports, particularly gasoline from Asia and compliance with Jones Act restrictions.
California imported nearly 50 kb/d of gasoline and blending components in 2024, largely from Asia, with few global refineries configured to meet the state's strict fuel standards.

sec.h: Natural Gas Liquids Drive Supply Growth
b: Global NGLs production is forecast to rise by 2.0 mb/d to 15.5 mb/d by 2030, with the United States, Saudi Arabia, and Canada accounting for 84% of current production and rising to 88% by 2030.

The United States maintains overwhelming dominance with 51% market share, production set to increase from 6.9 mb/d in 2024 to 7.8 mb/d in 2030, while the Middle East boosts its share from 25% to 29% over the same period.
Ethane demand expands by 610 kb/d from 2024 to 2030, reaching 5.2 mb/d, with the Middle East leading demand growth at 290 kb/d and the United States remaining both the largest exporter and consumer.

LPG consumption will increase by 1.3 mb/d to 11.8 mb/d by 2030, with East of Suez markets accounting for two-thirds of overall demand growth, gaining 820 kb/d over the outlook period to reach 6.6 mb/d.
Around 43% of LPG comes from refineries and the rest from NGL fractionation, with most incremental supply coming from fractionation which is forecast to rise 850 kb/d to 7.1 mb/d by 2030.

sec.h: Economic and Geopolitical Uncertainties Shape Outlook
b: Heightened geopolitical risks, unresolved trade tensions, and policy shifts have added uncertainties to oil market outlook, with major economic forecasters cutting world GDP growth in 2025 by roughly half a percentage point to around 2.8%.

Global GDP growth is projected to average near 3% over 2025-30, almost half a point lower than during the 2010s, amid structural headwinds including aging populations, increased protectionism, and stretched government finances.

The ratio of cross-border trade and investments to GDP has stalled over the past decade amid global retreat from free trade toward mercantilist policies, tariffs, and subsidies, with Baker, Bloom and Davis Global Economic Policy Uncertainty Index surging to highest level ever in April 2025.

China's growth will decline steadily over the outlook period, with GDP expansion sliding to 3.7% in 2030 from 7.3% in the 2010s, amid shrinking population, protracted property slump, and massive overcapacity challenges.

Ongoing tensions between Iran and Israel, impact of western sanctions on Russia, Iran and Venezuela, and changes in who is buying sanctioned barrels remain key uncertainties, with access to technologies, financing and supply chain inputs potentially further impacted.

sec.h: Investment and Exploration Trends Signal Industry Caution
b: Global upstream oil and gas investment is set to decline by 4% in 2025 to around USD 565 billion, with upstream oil investments on track to fall by nearly 6% to USD 420 billion according to company guidance.

The precipitous drop in oil prices in early 2025 and uncertain investment climate have prompted oil executives worldwide to reevaluate upstream priorities, with some of the largest declines in US light tight oil spending.

Average exploration capital from 2015-24 was 30% lower than the previous ten-year average at USD 35 billion, with correlation between exploration capex and oil prices changing from 0.9 over 2000-14 to effectively zero from 2015-24.

Just under 5 billion barrels of conventional liquid resources were discovered in 2024, replacing only 19% of conventional production last year, with four projects accounting for approximately half of discovered volumes.

Peak production from conventional projects sanctioned during 2021-24 is expected to average 2.5 mb/d annually, slightly exceeding the 2015-19 previous five-year average of 2.1 mb/d but showing deceleration in project sanctioning.
Working-from-home employment has reduced global road fuels demand by around 800 kb/d compared to 2019 levels, with this level of savings holding roughly steady through the forecast period to 2030.

The United States accounts for nearly 800 kb/d of fuel use being avoided through teleworking, with WFH's share of paid workdays remaining stable from 2022 onwards at around 25-30% after soaring to 60% during 2020 lockdowns.

Hybrid-driven vehicle fuel efficiency gains are cutting Japanese gasoline use, with Japan posting efficiency gains of around 1% per year and gasoline demand falling almost 15% below pre-pandemic levels in 2024 despite positive GDP growth.

Cultural individualism emerges as the main driver for variance in WFH rates across countries, with full-time employees working from home in excess of 1.5 days per week in the United States, Canada and UK, leading other developed economies.

Public transport use has been similarly transformed by the pandemic, with 2024 ridership in major European cities still 5-10% below pre-Covid levels and even larger declines in the United States, where subway ridership is 30% lower in New York and down 60% on California's BART system.

sec.h: Aviation and Marine Sectors Face Efficiency Pressures
b: The commercial aviation industry has completed recovery from the pandemic with record-high passenger numbers, but jet/kerosene consumption gains lag due to improved efficiencies counterbalancing robust underlying growth in air travel.
Jet/kerosene use may not regain pre-Covid levels until 2027, four years after flight activity passed the same mark, despite reasonably constructive underlying demand outlook for the aviation sector.

Advanced aircraft technologies including improved aerodynamics, lightweight materials, and enhanced engine propulsion combine to reduce drag, with new narrow-body models like Airbus320neo and Boeing 737 MAX about 20% more fuel-efficient than predecessors.

Demand for marine fuels is expected to flatline at around 5 mb/d over the forecast period as subpar underlying growth in shipping combines with rising costs from ongoing tightening of marine decarbonization standards.

UN International Maritime Organization emission standards will continue to tighten, with Mediterranean becoming Sulphur Emission Control Area in May 2025 and global greenhouse gas pricing system for merchant ships starting in 2028.

summaries.s: Jimmy Iovine

sec.h: Early Life and the Power of Inversion
b: Jimmy Iovine was born in Brooklyn to a longshoreman father who planned to get him a job at the docks after high school graduation
From a young age, Jimmy practiced what Charlie Munger called "inversion" - thinking about what he didn't want to do rather than what he did want to do
He knew he didn't want a normal life or normal job, instead wanting to do something special and extraordinary
His early passion was studying music for hours, reading album covers, and developing the ability to make others superfans of whatever he was passionate about
His family recognized this unique skill that would later become crucial to his career success

sec.h: First Breaks and the Importance of Mentorship
b: Through family connections, Jimmy met singer-songwriter Ellie Greenwich who got him his first two jobs in recording studios
He was fired from his first job sweeping floors and then fired on the 89th day of a 90-day trial period at his second job
Ellie Greenwich's persistence in helping him get a third chance at the Record Plant changed his entire life trajectory
At the Record Plant, he met Roy Cicala, a legendary engineer and producer who became his mentor and taught him by "working through him"
Jimmy learned the fundamental lesson that when you're in a position to help someone who deserves it, you should do whatever you can to help them
Jimmy's first major break came when Roy Cicala called him on Easter Sunday to test his commitment - John Lennon was in the studio
Despite his mother's objections about working on Easter, Jimmy showed up, demonstrating his "I'll do anything to make this work" mentality
Working with John Lennon, Jimmy focused on being of service - learning not just technical skills but making Lennon's tea perfectly
John Lennon gave Jimmy opportunities because he liked and trusted him, not necessarily because of raw talent
This experience taught Jimmy the importance of stepping forward despite fear and focusing on how to serve rather than impress

sec.h: Fear as a Tailwind - First Favorite Philosophy
b: Jimmy developed one of his core philosophies: using fear as a tailwind rather than letting it stand in front of you

His philosophy: "Fear's a powerful thing. It's got a lot of firepower. If you could figure out a way to wrestle that fear to push you from behind, rather than stand in front of you, that's very powerful"
He believed he had to work harder than the next person just to do as well, and to do better, he had to "kill it"
Jimmy trained himself that anytime he felt fear, he had to take a step forward
This mindset was crucial during his early experiences with intimidating figures like Phil Spector, who showed up to sessions with guns and created chaotic environments

sec.h: The Phil Spector Experience and Handling Chaos
b: John Lennon sent 20-year-old Jimmy to California to work with Phil Spector, his first time on a plane or in a hotel
Phil Spector arrived wearing a white butcher coat with two guns strapped to his chest, creating an environment of complete chaos
Jimmy had to navigate three weeks of recording with Phil yelling, drinking, and even shooting up the studio bathroom
He witnessed confrontations between Phil Spector and David Geffen, realizing that successful people had the same conflicts he saw in Brooklyn
This experience reinforced his understanding that he had to work through turbulent environments without second chances
Jimmy's father was his best friend and biggest cheerleader, constantly telling him "Whatever room you go into is better because you are there"
This parental support gave Jimmy confidence and helped him never feel like he didn't belong in any situation
Despite having natural insecurities and fear, his father's encouragement helped him develop the confidence to take on challenges
The relationship with his father became one of the most important and influential in his life
This foundation of confidence would prove crucial as he worked with increasingly prominent musicians and industry figures

sec.h: Bruce Springsteen and the Work Ethic Revolution
b: Working with Bruce Springsteen in 1975 taught Jimmy what a real work ethic looked like for the first time
Bruce's philosophy was "you don't stop until you get it right," spending three weeks just trying to get drum sounds perfect
Springsteen's relentless pursuit of excellence exposed mediocrity in everyone around him
Bruce would stand over Jimmy saying "Stick, stick, stick" for three weeks, meaning hit the drum again because it wasn't producing the right size and power
This experience taught Jimmy that when pushing boundaries and moving into new frontiers, you need people who truly believe in what you're doing

sec.h: The Big Picture Philosophy and Staying in the Saddle
b: When Jimmy almost quit due to exhaustion and pressure, Bruce's manager gave him life-changing advice about staying focused on the big picture
The advice: "We're not here to make you happy. We're here to contribute to Bruce's project. Focus on helping Bruce make the best record he can"
Jimmy learned that if you focus on being of service and caring as much about their project as they do, you'll have friends for life
This "big picture" thinking became a recurring theme Jimmy applied throughout his career
The result was the album "Born to Run," which became one of the greatest albums ever made and is still on top 100 lists 50 years later

sec.h: The Dangers of Success and Breathing Your Own Exhaust
b: After the success of "Born to Run," Jimmy experienced what he called "breathing your own exhaust" - getting comfortable with success
He made mistakes like bringing his girlfriend to recording sessions and living the lifestyle instead of focusing on the work
This led to getting fired from his next project with the band Foghat, teaching him that success can be dangerous
Jimmy learned the maxim: "If you go to sleep on a win, you'll wake up with a loss"
He realized that most people aren't paying attention to your failures the way you think they are, and embarrassment can be a powerful motivator to recommit

sec.h: Professional Research and the Patti Smith Collaboration
b: After his failure, Jimmy recommitted with the philosophy "no fun, no life, no nothing - you are giving up everything"
He developed a unique form of professional research: finding old tapes and seeing if he could improve them
Jimmy would spend hours studying music, staying late to practice and perfect his craft
His collaboration with Patti Smith resulted in the hit "Because the Night," which came from a Bruce Springsteen song that wasn't being used
This taught him to leverage relationships and unused material from prolific artists to create new opportunities
Jimmy recognized that being prolific is highly correlated with greatness - while being prolific doesn't guarantee greatness, great artists are typically prolific
He observed this pattern in Bruce Springsteen, who wrote countless songs he never used
Jimmy learned to identify these unused gems and match them with other artists who could bring them to life
The example of Prince writing a song a day and having over 8,000 unreleased songs illustrates this principle
Jimmy developed the skill of seeing potential in unused material and connecting it with the right artists

sec.h: Tom Petty and the Art of Persuasion
b: Working with Tom Petty, Jimmy demonstrated his persuasive abilities and obsession with getting the perfect take
They would do over 100 takes of songs like "Here Comes My Girl" and "Refugee" until they got it right
Jimmy's response to hearing these songs was immediate: "Get another eight songs quick, because we're done. We're going to be millionaires"
He became known as a "tornado of promotion" who wanted control over marketing because record executives often gave terrible feedback
Jimmy's philosophy was "Great is success" - focus on making something great first, then figure out how to expose it to more people

sec.h: Strategic Talent Recognition and Relationship Building
b: Jimmy consistently demonstrated an ability to identify and surround himself with the best people in the industry
Tom Petty noted: "One thing about Jimmy Iovine is he's always known which people to hang around with"
This mirrors Steve Jobs' approach of consistently figuring out who the really smart people were
Jimmy worked with John Lennon, Springsteen, Tom Petty, Dr. Dre, Eminem, and Trent Reznor - always betting on the highest talent
His strategy was to find the best people, then empower them completely rather than trying to control their creative process

sec.h: Personal Relationships and the Cost of Obsession
b: Jimmy's intensity in dating mirrored his professional approach - calling 10 times the next day, sending limousines with personalized napkins
His first wife Vicky described him as someone who "doesn't want to wait for people" and was completely driven
Their 25-year marriage ended in divorce, highlighting the tension between genius-level focus and normal family life
Vicky introduced Jimmy to Bono, demonstrating how personal relationships could create professional opportunities
The marriage produced four children but ultimately couldn't survive Jimmy's all-consuming focus on his work

sec.h: U2 and Bono: Pattern Recognition in Talent
b: When Jimmy first saw young Bono, he immediately recognized "the same thing that Springsteen had - he had the edge"
Bono initially resisted working with Jimmy due to their different styles, but Jimmy pursued them relentlessly around the world
Bono described Jimmy as "like a virus that takes over your organs and your brains" who wouldn't take no for an answer
Jimmy recognized that Bono and U2 had the same extreme work ethic as Springsteen
Bono valued Jimmy's "gift of clear thought" and ability to hear the clear melody in ideas and apply it universally
1984 marked the worst period of Jimmy's life when his father, grandfather, and grandmother all died within six weeks
Losing his father was devastating as they were best friends, and Jimmy says it remains the worst day of his life
This tragedy coincided with starting his own family and realizing he needed a major pivot in his career
After 18 years of producing, Jimmy was burnt out and wanted to stop working all night and missing time with his kids
The combination of personal loss and professional burnout led him to seek a transition from producing to business

sec.h: Learning from David Geffen and Starting Interscope
b: Jimmy sought advice from David Geffen after seeing that he "does what I do, but he just made all this money"
Geffen encouraged him: "You should do it. There are a lot of record people a lot dumber than you are"
Geffen became a mentor, teaching Jimmy "the art of business in music" when he knew nothing about business
Geffen's assessment: "If people think you're serious and you're easy to understand, they will help you"
Jimmy was described as "a sponge" who "picked up everything he heard or saw" - the same quality Springsteen had noticed years earlier

sec.h: Finding His Niche: Producing the Producers
b: Jimmy realized his competitive edge would be different from other record executives who were starting labels
His insight: "I didn't feel comfortable around executives. I felt comfortable around artists and record producers"
He developed the strategy of finding great producers and producing them, rather than trying to manage artists directly
This led to working with Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails, where Jimmy spent a year making daily 6 AM phone calls to resolve contract disputes
His approach was based on empathy, understanding everyone's motivations, and outlasting others through pure persistence

sec.h: The Phone as Theater of War
b: Bono described "The phone is Jimmy's theater of war. That is where he is deadly"
Jimmy would lock himself in the bathroom and stay on the phone all day with "red-hot, nuclear focus"
His wife described his phone-based negotiations as having an intensity that wouldn't give up
Jimmy's advantage was endurance: "This is a war of attrition. By endurance we conquer. I can outlast anybody"
He succeeded in the Nine Inch Nails deal by understanding everyone's primal motivations and what would move them

sec.h: Empowering Artists: The Keys and Drive Philosophy
b: When Jimmy finally met Trent Reznor after a year of negotiations, he asked simply: "What do you want?"
Trent wanted an advance, complete creative freedom, and his own label to sign other bands
Jimmy's response was consistently: "Okay, what else do you want?" until Trent couldn't think of anything
His philosophy: "When you have great artists, what you do is you give them the keys and you say, 'Drive'"
Jimmy refused to compromise great talent by telling artists like Tupac or Trent Reznor to change their lyrics or style

sec.h: Meeting Dr. Dre: Recognizing Revolutionary Talent
b: When Dr. Dre came to play "The Chronic" before its release, Jimmy immediately recognized it as "one of the greatest recordings I'd ever heard"
Dre's sonics were "far superior to any rock or hip-hop record being made" and sounded better than anything on Jimmy's speakers
When Jimmy asked who produced and engineered it, Dre's answer of "Me" to both questions convinced Jimmy this would "define Interscope"
Jimmy gave Suge Knight and Dr. Dre three weeks to clear up lawsuits, threatening to withdraw if they shopped around
This began a three-decade partnership that would culminate in them becoming billionaires together
Jimmy maintained "mad, obsessed focus on the big picture" - making the best record label in the world
He modeled Interscope after Atlantic Records in the 1970s, which had Ray Charles, Led Zeppelin, Aretha Franklin, and the Rolling Stones
The strategy was simple: "We need the best. We're going to bet on talent"
Bruce Springsteen noted Jimmy's ability to let go of what made him successful to pursue something greater
Jimmy was described as "an animal, the most driven and brilliant person" who "was never off" and didn't understand why others weren't the same way
When Dr. Dre's first two albums on Aftermath Records flopped, corporate partners pressured Jimmy to drop him
Jimmy's response: "Yeah, we could do that. And then you'll save my salary as well, because I'm going with him"
This loyalty was rewarded when Jimmy helped Dre discover Eminem during listening sessions at Jimmy's house
Jimmy played an Eminem demo, leading to Dre asking "What the fuck? Who the fuck is that?"
The principle: "Opportunity is a strange beast. It frequently appears after a loss"

sec.h: The Eminem Discovery and Great from Anywhere
b: Eminem handed out his demo at the Rap Olympics to someone who worked for Jimmy
Jimmy's philosophy: "Great can come from anywhere" - they weren't looking for a white controversial rapper, just great talent
Despite boycotts and pressure to police Eminem's lyrics, Jimmy remained consistent: "Let him be him"
Eminem became the bestselling rap artist of all time and top 10 bestselling musician overall
This vindicated Jimmy's loyalty to Dr. Dre and his belief in focusing on greatness regardless of its source

sec.h: The Racehorse Philosophy - Second Favorite Idea
b: Jimmy's second core philosophy emerged during the Eminem controversy: "I don't give a fuck what anyone thinks"
His analogy: "When you're a racehorse, they put blinders on because if you look at the horse on the left or right, you're going to miss a step"
"That's what people should have. When you're running after something, you should not look left and right. What does this person think? What does that person think? No, go"
This philosophy guided him through industry pressure and public controversy
Jimmy kept this quote on his phone and listened to it repeatedly for years as motivation

sec.h: The Birth of Beats: From Music to Technology
b: Seeing the music industry's shift from CDs to iTunes to streaming, Jimmy decided he didn't want to be "the guy that sells the last CD"
During his divorce, frustrated with both the music business and personal life, he buried himself in work as his only therapeutic method
When Dr. Dre mentioned a sneaker endorsement offer, Jimmy interrupted: "Sneakers? You should do speakers. Speakers and headphones"
Jimmy immediately left, then days later called Dre to his office where he had assembled a hundred different headphone designs
This demonstrated Jimmy's pattern: speed, going all in, and doing more reps than anyone else

sec.h: Beats Marketing Genius and Distribution Strategy
b: Jimmy recognized that existing headphone marketing was wrong - Bose sold noise-canceling as putting you to sleep
Beats positioning: "We don't want to put you to sleep. We want to make you move. We looked at it as motivation and emotion"
Distribution strategy: "If we get our headphones on the best musicians and athletes, that will cause people to try them, and the great sound will get them to stay"
Jimmy carried headphones to every meeting, made everyone try them, and took pictures for marketing
He insisted on Beats appearing in all music videos and courted controversy when they were banned from Olympics and NFL

sec.h: The Apple Acquisition and Ride or Die Loyalty
b: Apple bought both the Beats streaming service and headphones for $3 billion
During secret negotiations, Jimmy told Dre to stay quiet, but Dre got drunk and filmed a video with Tyrese announcing he was a billionaire
Jimmy was worried this would spike the deal but remained loyal: "This is the horse I rode in with. I ride or die with Dre"
The deal went through, making both Jimmy and Dre billionaires
This demonstrated Jimmy's consistency in maintaining loyalty even when partners made mistakes

sec.h: Retirement Philosophy and No Rear-View Mirror
b: Jimmy retired while still driven because "I didn't want to be driven anymore" - it was a conscious decision
When Bruce Springsteen asked why he was retiring, Jimmy said he was tired of talking to "scumbags all day"
His philosophy on regrets: "I don't have a rear-view mirror. With the rear-view mirror you're taking victory laps and those are a waste of time"
"I'm more like, let's go. What's new? What's tomorrow? I made a lot of mistakes. Who doesn't? But I don't care about the mistakes"
Final advice echoed his racehorse philosophy: Don't look left and right wondering what others think - just go
